title: I feel that some changes to how shielding works needs to come soon after these Marksmen changes.
body:
I'm an ADC main, and everything I read on the marksmen changes seem pretty good so far. However, on Reddit, there was one comment line talking about how assassins may have more time to actually kill their target before being bursted down by the ADC (around 1 to 2 seconds.......which is a VERY long time in League). However, that line ended with a comment saying "God Bless Lulu."

And that made me realize.....all these changes not only make assassins better, but also, in turn, make shielding supports better. If these changes go through......not much may change except for which support is taken. We may very well not fall into the World's Ardent meta again, but the strong scaling ADCs we have today may still stick around due to having a "get-out-of-jail-free-card" in their back pocket.

Take Janna for example. All of these changes could be indirect buffs for her, since she has notoriously been a "mid to late game support". Her laning sucks.....ALOT, but once you start getting into teamfights is where she truly starts to shine. According to the changes, ADCs will "turn on" later in the game.......right where Janna wants to be. Pair her with a Twitch or Tristana, and, well......we're right back to where we are now, just slightly later in the game.

Just my 2 cents......I guess we'll just have to wait and see.

Personally, I feel the issue with the support changes over recent times is that they've focused exclusively on increasing their defenses, to the detriment of everything else. As a Lulu main, you likely know far better than I do that she's actually a really versatile champion with a ton of offensive effects (in fact, her combination of offense and utility is what allowed her to solo lane), yet since the introduction of the healing/shielding stat she's been relegated to the same spot as Janna, where she exists purely to save the marksman's life, shut down incoming assassins and divers, and otherwise do little else. Moreover, Lulu as a champion has immense potential to synergize with melee allies, due to her bonus health/size/slow aura on ult and increased movement speed buff on W, but her ult has ended up being treated as a pure heal, whereas her W was changed by Riot themselves to synergize primarily with marksmen.

Because of this, while I agree shields and heals need to be pared down significantly overall, I think enchanters should also have their offensive playmaking abilities buffed and valued more in compensation. Ideally, "offensive playmaking" should not necessarily mean more damage, as was the case with Janna's horrendous mini-rework, but should involve the ability to enhance the offensive potential of allies, as well as set targets up with CC. Nami is a popular champion precisely because she has such a great balance between her capabilities for both offensive and defensive plays, and I think even the most defensive of supports could opt into this as well. Having support items that encouraged offensive plays, namely by rewarding offensive power and synergizing with setups, instead of the current selection that offers almost exclusively defensive effects like heals and shields, could go a long way towards allowing enchanters to thrive, without having to exist purely as a provider of extra health bars and items for only one champion on their whole team.

It is indeed usually difficult to discern the meaning of a point when one stops right in the middle of it. In the very excerpt you have quoted, I literally mentioned "the ability to enhance the offensive potential of allies, as well as set targets up with CC" as examples of offensive power. A steroid that gives movement speed when moving towards enemies, for example, is a form of offensive utility. I agree that most crowd control can be used both offensively and defensively (though even then, that differs from healing and shielding), but one can still find plenty of ways to bias that CC towards offense: for example, Ivern's root is more offensive because it gives champions a free dash to the rooted target, and Leona's CC tends to be more offensive because it marks targets for bonus damage. By contrast, Janna's CC tends to be more defensive, because her displacement originates from her location, and tends to be more difficult to dodge for opponents moving directly towards her or a nearby ally, while only much more rarely being good at making picks. In view of this, I'd support making crowd control on some supports more offensively-oriented via these kinds of effects, or by giving them items that would similarly enable better offense using this kind of utility or CC (for example, an item that caused your hard CC to temporarily reduce the target's resists).

The fact that it's picked even on supports intended to be more offensive is evidence enough that that kind of build is far too strong, or at least that builds with more offensive utility aren't nearly as popular by comparison. > Ardent is an item that primarily operates through heals and shields, while also boosting them, so even though its effects are offensive, it still contributes to the excessive amount of healing and shielding we have now, even without the ridiculous sustain it used to have.

Ive had more success with it on Tankier supports who actually build HP myself.

The reason it still gets use is because the item itself is just to reliable stat check and always has been.
To my knowledge, Riot was playing with Changes to rework the item all together, so i wouldn't preoccupy myself with the item too much.

In any case, Athenes is honestly very underrated imho. As for Twin Shadows, while ive seen some fringe purchase cases, it doesn't get bought for the same reason i said it wouldnt when Riot thought bringing it back would be a good compromise for removing FQC.
It just doesn't complement these champion's skill set. Instead, it offers situational isolated power purley on the active, as opposed to something like Shurelias which is has more general usefulness. when ti was FQC, it was an optional upgrade for an item you were already gonna get, which incentivised actually getting it.

But some people insisted I was wrong so i brought it up anyway. 

> For sure, we have some offensive support items, or at least some support items that can be used offensively, but currently the most prominent and popular support items contribute to a very protection-oriented build.

But here is the thing. Ultimately, Enchanters and Wardens as supports ARE primarily intended to be protection oriented in general. 
The reason protection oriented items have historically, (yes, historically, even before Forbidden idol items) been the most effective on them is because these items actually help these champions do what they are trying to do primarily.

While I don't think adding additional options in the spirit of giving these champions more build options, I don't think steering them away from performing their primary function is exactly what the intent should be.

(cont)

>The fact that it's picked even on supports intended to be more offensive is evidence enough that that kind of build is far too strong, or at least that builds with more offensive utility aren't nearly as popular by comparison. This is what needs to change.

I looked up Bard, and apparently Twin Shadows is popular on him, which makes sense with his roam focused playstyle and the fact he benefits from the MS.

but people shot the idea down saying it would be to abusable.

If this needs to change, it would take a far larger systemic change than simply introducing a few new items imo.
Tho again, i don't think it is all that pressing an issue when it comes to the overall balance of the role.

If all these champs are building these items, then if the role is to strong, the items are too strong.

tho i still ascribe to the idea that supports benefited from runes more than most champions in the game.
Runes are largely responsible for the increased early power supports have right now, and that was only made more potent with purchasing Sightstone not being a thing, saving them on 800g.

> [{quoted}](name=ChaddyFantome,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=c5OfQJNX,comment-id=00020001000000000000,timestamp=2018-05-03T00:14:46.088+0000)

Here is the literal quote from Riot's own definition of enchanters:

> Enchanters focus on amplifying their allies’ effectiveness by directly augmenting them and defending them from incoming threats. Enchanters themselves are often quite fragile and bring relatively low damage to the table, meaning they really only shine when grouped together with others.

So, as a matter of fact, augmenting the potency of allies is put on equal footing with protection. This is also putting aside how these class definitions are retroactive and can easily be subject to change depending on the class's health.

> [{quoted}](name=ChaddyFantome,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=c5OfQJNX,comment-id=00020001000000000000,timestamp=2018-05-03T00:14:46.088+0000)

> While I don't think adding additional options in the spirit of giving these champions more build options, I don't think steering them away from performing their primary function is exactly what the intent should be.

Alright then, let's just flatly nerf supports instead and call it a day. Because that is the only alternative here: at the end of the day, supports output too many defenses, and regardless of whether or not that is their "intent", that is unhealthy to the game. What I am proposing here is to avoid this kind of situation by _shifting_ power from defense to offense, instead of simply _removing_ it.
